sections.title: People-First Process Design
sections.content: Too often, business process design starts with technology capabilities or theoretical efficiency models. Better approach: start with how people actually work, then design processes that amplify their strengths while minimizing friction.

items.title: Technology-First Thinking
items.description: Processes designed around system capabilities rather than user needs, leading to workarounds and shadow processes.
items.impact: 40% lower adoption rates, increased training costs

items.title: Over-Optimization
items.description: Pursuit of theoretical efficiency that ignores human factors like cognitive load, error recovery, and edge cases.
items.impact: Brittle processes that break under real-world conditions

items.title: Compliance Theater
items.description: Processes designed to satisfy auditors rather than enable productive work, creating bureaucratic overhead.
items.impact: Decreased productivity, increased resistance to change

sections.title: Case Study: Progressive Insurance Legal Review Process
sections.description: State filing processes required legal review coordination across multiple departments, creating bottlenecks and compliance risks.
sections.approach: Designed collaborative workflow that integrated legal review into development process rather than treating it as separate approval gate.
sections.innovation: Created early-warning system that flagged potential legal issues during content creation, preventing downstream bottlenecks.
sections.results: 60% reduction in review cycle time, 75% fewer compliance issues, 85% process satisfaction improvement
